---
title: "Example worksheet"
format: live-html
engine: knitr
---


::: {.cell}

:::



Non-exercise math


::: {.cell}
```{webr}
2 + 3
```
:::



Exercise math


::: {.cell exercise='math'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: math
2 + 3
```
:::


## Packages


::: {.cell}
```{webr}
install.packages("dplyr", quiet = TRUE)
library(dplyr)

starwars |>
  filter(height < 100) |>
  select(name, height, mass)
```
:::



::: {.cell exercise='assignment'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: assignment
x ______ 5
```
:::


::: { .solution exercise="assignment" }
::: { .callout-tip title="Solution" collapse="false"}
The assignment operator
```r
x <- 5
```
:::
:::

Exercises have their own environment, so `x` has to be redefined.


::: {.cell exercise='variable'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: variable
x <- 5
x * 2
```
:::



You can manually manage environments


::: {.cell envir='myenv' exercise='env'}
```{webr}
#| envir: myenv
#| exercise: env
x ______ 5
```
:::



::: {.cell envir='myenv' exercise='env2'}
```{webr}
#| envir: myenv
#| exercise: env2
x * 2
```
:::


## setup


::: {.cell setup='true' exercise='ex_2'}
```{webr}
#| setup: true
#| exercise: ex_2
foo <- 1
bar <- 2
baz <- 3
```
:::



::: {.cell exercise='ex_2'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: ex_2
foo + bar + baz + ______
```
:::


Make `x` a vector of numbers.


::: {.cell exercise='vect'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: vect
x
```
:::


::: { .hint exercise="vect" }
::: { .callout-note collapse="false" }
## Hint 1

Make sure to use the assignment operator (`<-`)

```r
x <- ______
```
:::
:::

::: { .hint exercise="vect"}
::: { .callout-note collapse="false"}
## Hint 2

Vectors are created using the `c()` function, which stands for combine.

```r
x <- c(______)
```
:::
:::

::: { .solution exercise="vect" }
::: { .callout-tip collapse="false"}
## Fully worked solution:

Values within `c()` are separated by commas.

```r
x <- c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)
```

:::
:::


You can also put exercises in a tabset: Make `y` a vector of numbers.

:::: {.panel-tabset}

## Exercise


::: {.cell exercise='ex_4'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: ex_4
y
```
:::


## Hint 1

::: { .hint exercise="ex_4"}
Vectors are created using the `c()`, which stands for combine.

```r
y ______ c(______)
```
:::

## Hint 2

::: { .hint exercise="ex_4"}
Vectors are created using the `c()` function, which stands for combine.

```r
y <- c(______)
```
:::

## Solution

::: { .solution exercise="ex_4" }

```r
y <- c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)
```
:::

::::

## Andrew Heiss style

Multiply the values by a number.

::: {.panel-tabset}
## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor

```{webr-r}
c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)
```

## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution

```r
c(1, 3, 5, 7, 9) * 2
```

:::

`webr` cells that are not editable act like normal `r` cells, but they can place objects into the global environment.


::: {.cell edit='false'}
```{webr}
#| edit: false
names <- c("John", "Lily", "Mark", "Anna")
```
:::


Empty exercise block


::: {.cell exercise='variables'}
```{webr}
#| exercise: variables
```
:::


Can run help. Prints out help file. An 


::: {.cell}
```{webr}
?mean
```
:::
